**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant that the tenant shall have the quiet enjoyment of the premises for the term of the lease.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant that the tenant shall have the quiet enjoyment of the premises for the term of the lease.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to an "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment and analyzes whether the landlords breached that covenant in a residential lease context. The court treats this covenant as a standard, existing obligation in leases and frames the constructive eviction issue as arising from the landlords’ violation of that implied covenant. Although the case’s main focus is on when a landlord’s conduct constitutes a breach, it clearly assumes and applies the rule that such an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment is part of the residential lease.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge... The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment... Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment...

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of their leased premises caused by the landlord or by acts authorized or tolerated by the landlord.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and explains that it protects tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, focusing on the landlord’s conduct rather than subjective intent. It holds that liability arises where the landlord’s acts or omissions, including tolerating or failing to prevent conditions like repeated flooding, have the natural and probable consequence of interfering with the tenant’s rights. This directly supports the proposition that quiet enjoyment covers substantial interferences caused by the landlord or by conduct the landlord authorizes or tolerates.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … [M]ore recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of their leased premises caused by the landlord or by acts authorized or tolerated by the landlord.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions the tenant’s counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and notes that the judge found such a breach, but it awards no damages on that claim and, more importantly, does not discuss or articulate the legal standard for quiet enjoyment. The court’s analysis focuses almost entirely on the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in the context of a subsidized tenancy. Because the decision neither defines the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment nor explains that it covers substantial interferences caused by the landlord or acts the landlord authorizes or tolerates, it does not provide direct authority for the claimed proposition.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: The presence of disruptive noise and dust caused by Defendant’s construction project rendered the premises partially unsuitable for the ordinary and lawful purposes intended, violating *G.L. c. 186, § 14* and the implied covenant under *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion does not deal with disruptive noise, dust, or construction conditions at all; it concerns lead paint and whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself, constitutes a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. The SJC holds that some degree of landlord fault (at least negligence with notice) is required for a quiet enjoyment violation and explicitly rejects automatic liability based solely on a statutory violation. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that construction-related noise and dust, by themselves, render premises partially unsuitable in violation of § 14 and the implied covenant.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The length and intensity of the construction—continuing daily for multiple months without adequate mitigation—distinguish it as a substantial, not trivial, interference within the meaning of *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landlord’s failure to provide heat and holds that such failure breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of financial inability or intent. It does not discuss construction activities, distinctions between substantial versus trivial interferences, or any analysis based on the length and intensity of construction. Using Lowery v. Robinson as authority for a proposition about extended construction as a substantial interference misstates the case’s subject and holding.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant had notice of the conditions and failed to take reasonable steps to remedy them, in violation of *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case does discuss the landlord’s obligations once it has notice of uninhabitable conditions, but it explicitly rejects any requirement that the landlord take “reasonable steps to remedy” those conditions as a prerequisite to the tenant’s remedies. Instead, Berman holds that the tenant’s rent obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice of the breach, regardless of the landlord’s fault or the reasonableness of its repair efforts. Thus, it does not support the proposition that liability turns on failure to take reasonable steps to remedy after notice.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability. The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent. … The tenant may now withhold rent without considering whether the landlord is at fault or is taking reasonable steps to repair.”

*Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. App.raw_text: *Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1103 (1989) (landlord’s after-the-fact offer does not cure a continuing violation).
*Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. App.proposition: Defendant’s offer of a nominal rent reduction does not absolve or mitigate his legal responsibility for the ongoing breach.
*Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the denial of a motion to suppress evidence in a criminal drug case and analyzes the legality of a vehicle stop and subsequent search. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, rent, contract modification, or any issue about whether an after-the-fact offer (such as a nominal rent reduction) can cure or mitigate an ongoing breach. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about a defendant’s offer of a nominal rent reduction and appears to be a miscitation or placeholder error.
